title: Kant’s view of free will presented in this chapter appears in his Critique of Pure Reason and Foundations of the Metaphysics of Morals. Chisholm’s agent-causal view as expressed in “Human Freedom and the Self
Thomas Reid’s agent-causal view is sympathetically examined in William Rowe’s Thomas Reid on Freedom and Morality
Augustine’s classic work on foreknowledge and freedom is On the Free Choice of the Will
A selection from this work can be found in my edited volume Free Will
Two fine general studies of the problem of divine foreknowledge and human freedom are William Hasker’s God, Time and Knowledge

note: The Open Theist view is defended by Clark Pinnock, Richard Rice, John Sanders, William Hasker, and David Basinger in The Openness of God
title: Zagzebski’s The Dilemma of Freedom and Foreknowledge
Luis de Molina’s view can be found in On Divine Foreknowledge, translated with a useful introduction by Alfredo Freddoso
The most thorough modern defense of the Molinist view is Thomas Flint’s Divine Providence: The Molinist Account
Robert Merrihow Adams’s critique of Molinism can be found in “Middle Knowledge and the Problem of Evil
The Open Theist view of process philosophers such as Whitehead and Hartshorne is readably introduced
